sn12.51:3.1: Pali is rich in expressions for inner reflection and investigation. Sometimes this process is called “inner self-examination” (SN 12.66:3.3, sometimes “rational application of mind” (SN 12.4:2.3).
sn12.51:9.1: This is one of the passages showing that the primary sense of saṅkhāra is moral “choices” either good, bad, or “imperturbable”. See also MN 57:9.2, AN 3.23, AN 4.233. | The suffix -upaga indicates “passing on” to rebirth in a new life. The compound puññūpaga parallels kammupaga and means “passes on by means of goodness” (resolve to puññena upagataṁ).
sn12.51:9.3: The fourth absorption and above are called “imperturbable” (āneñja) because they are associated with equanimous feeling. This is technically distinguished from “good” or “meritorious” (puñña) choices, whose outcome is pleasant feeling.
sn12.51:9.4: This shows that the sense of “choices” here is morally pregnant: they make no choice productive of future lives. They still make “choices” which are in line with the good, they just don’t have any kammic effect.
sn12.51:9.6: Letting go is not just a conceptual matter, it has immediate emotional consequences. Paritassati conveys the twin senses of desire and agitation, for which “anxiety” seems the best fit.
sn12.51:10.1: This describes the reflective experience of the arahant.
sn12.51:11.2: To “become cool” is, as the simile makes clear, to realize extinguishment (nibbāna).
